The event was attended by leading experts in various fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).During his address, President Obama highlighted the importance of science and technology in driving the US economy and improving people's lives. He also praised the honorees for their groundbreaking research and innovation, which has had a significant impact on various fields of study.The honorees included a diverse group of individuals, ranging from leading academics to cutting-edge entrepreneurs. Some of the notable awardees were Dr. John Kanzius, a cancer researcher who has made significant strides in developing novel therapies for cancer patients, and Dr. Anita Jones, a renowned materials scientist who has made significant contributions to the field of nanotechnology.Other honorees included Dr. Eric Lander, a geneticist who has played a key role in mapping the human genome, and Dr. Leroy Hood, a biomedical engineer who has developed pioneering technologies in the field of genomics.In addition to the awards, President Obama also announced several new initiatives aimed at boosting STEM education and innovation in the US. These initiatives include a new grant program to support research in cutting-edge fields like synthetic biology and nanotechnology, as well as a mentorship program to help young scientists and innovators connect with experienced professionals in their field.Speaking at the event, Dr. Anita Jones highlighted the importance of diversity in STEM fields, saying that "in order to drive innovation, we need a diverse range of perspectives and experiences." She also praised the President's initiatives, saying that they would "go a long way in supporting the next generation of scientists and innovators."

GAZA CITY, GAZA STRIP - Egypt on Wednesday trucked 1 million liters of cheap diesel fuel to the Gaza Strip's sole power plant — a rare shipment that temporarily eased a crippling electricity crisis in the Hamas-ruled enclave but also appeared to undercut Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.Abbas has been stepping up financial pressure on Gaza in hopes of forcing the militant group Hamas to cede ground in the territory. Hamas seized Gaza from Abbas' forces in 2007. The power plant stopped operating in April after Hamas could no longer afford to buy heavily taxed fuel from Abbas' West Bank-based government, leaving Gazans with just four hours of electricity a day. Abbas also asked Israel to reduce the electricity it sends to Gaza, which amounts to about a third of the territory's needs. This electricity, paid for by the Abbas government, has been reduced by one-fourth since Monday, worsening the crunch. The power shortage has cast a pall over the current holy month of Ramadan, when Muslims often end their dawn-to-dusk fasting with lavish family meals. With their homes in the dark and refrigerators not functioning, families have had to scale back the celebrations. Yousef al-Kayali, a Hamas finance official, said 11 trucks delivered the fuel on Wednesday. He said a second shipment of an additional 1 million liters was expected by Thursday. The fuel will not solve Gaza's electricity woes, however. Israel is now providing just 88 megawatts of power each day, down from 120 megawatts earlier this week.

TEHRAN – Iran's oil exports have faltered and its trade with Germany and the United States has slumped, a senior government official said on Tuesday, as tensions between Tehran and Western powers escalate.The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the decline in oil exports was due to increased pressure from Western countries, which have been urging their firms to stop doing business with Iran."The situation is not good. We are facing many problems with our oil exports and trade with Germany and the US," the official told reporters. "It's not just a temporary problem, it's a structural issue."The news comes as tensions between Iran and the West continue to rise over Iran's disputed nuclear program. The United States and its allies have imposed sanctions on Iran, targeting its oil exports and financial transactions.Iran has threatened to block the Strait of Hormuz, a vital shipping lane for global oil exports, if it is unable to sell its own crude. The US has responded by saying it would take all necessary measures to protect its interests in the region.The decline in trade with Germany and the US is likely to have a significant impact on Iran's economy. The two countries are among Iran's biggest trading partners.Analysts say that the escalating tensions could lead to a wider conflict in the region, which would have serious implications for global oil supplies and stability."It's a very delicate situation, and there is a risk of things getting out of control," said one analyst, who asked not to be named.

Palestinian medics say a young Palestinian girl has been killed in an Israeli air strike in the Gaza Strip, after an Israeli died in a cross-border mortar attackA Palestinian mortar shell fired from the Gaza Strip slammed into an Israeli kibbutz (collective farm), Thursday. It resulted in the second killing of a kibbutz resident in two weeks."The situation is intolerable," said Chaim Yalin, the head of the regional council in the area. He told Israel Radio that Gaza border communities have been bombarded daily for years and the that government and army are doing nothing. He says Israelis are being buried every week and that no one seems to care.The Islamic militant group Hamas, which rules Gaza, claims responsibility for the attack. Hamas issued a statement saying that it would confront what it calls "the occupier," because of what Hamas calls its continuing aggression against the Palestinian people. Hamas is especially angry about a crippling Israeli blockade on Gaza, imposed in response to the rocket and mortar fire.Israeli Cabinet Minister Roni Bar-On says there is only one solution.Bar-On told Israel Radio that the army must launch a major offensive in Gaza, to put an end to the Palestinian cross-border attacks.

The new season of ABC's hit show "Dancing with the Stars" boasts an impressive lineup of celebrities, including N'Sync's Joey Fatone and country music star Billy Ray Cyrus.Other notable names set to compete in the upcoming season include reality TV personalities, an Olympic gold medalist, and a former NFL player.Fatone, who rose to fame as a member of N'Sync, has been a fan of dance music for a long time. "I've always been a huge fan of dance music, and to be able to dance with the pros on 'Dancing with the Stars' is a dream come true," he said in a statement.Cyrus, known for his hit song "Achy Breaky Heart," is also excited about the opportunity to show off his dance skills. "I've always been into dancing, and to be able to do it on 'Dancing with the Stars' is going to be so much fun," he said.In addition to Fatone and Cyrus, the new season of "Dancing with the Stars" will feature a number of other notable celebrities, including former NFL player Terrell Owens, reality TV personality Kirstie Alley, and Olympic gold medalist Lolo Jones.The new season of "Dancing with the Stars" is set to premiere on September 16th on ABC.

Japan is still pushing for sanctions against North Korea for last week's missile tests - a day after the U.N. Security Council delayed a vote to allow more time for diplomacy. Meanwhile, South Korea has criticized Japan for talk of possible pre-emptive military action against North Korea - saying it is intensifying the crisis.Japan's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Tomohiko Taniguchi, says Tokyo still wants U.N. Security Council sanctions imposed on North Korea for its July 5 missile tests in the Sea of Japan."But we have just decided to put on hold for 24 hours or maximum 48 hours for the Chinese will come back with more concrete ideas about what North Korea has had to say to China," said Taniguchi.The Security Council delayed a vote Monday to allow a Chinese delegation to talk to the North Koreans in Pyongyang.U.S. envoy, Christopher Hill is in Asia to get regional governments to respond with one voice.But differences persist. China opposes U.N. sanctions. South Korea questions their effectiveness. Japan is talking about changing its pacifist stance to allow pre-emptive military action against North Korea - something South Korea criticized Tuesday as reckless.

Baghdad, Iraq - In a country torn apart by war and political strife, a small radio station is making waves with its commitment to freedom of speech and open dialogue.Iraq Talk, a radio station based in Baghdad, has become a haven for those looking to express their opinions and ideas without fear of retribution or censorship.Founded by Mohammed Jassim, a journalist with over 20 years of experience in the field, Iraq Talk has quickly become a popular destination for Iraqis seeking a platform to voice their views.Jassim, who also hosts a daily talk show on the station, says he created Iraq Talk to give people a space to express themselves freely and to encourage dialogue and understanding between different communities in Iraq."We believe that freedom of speech is a fundamental right that should be available to everyone," Jassim said. "Our mission is to provide a platform for people to express their opinions and ideas without fear of persecution or censorship."Iraq Talk's programming includes a mix of news, politics, and cultural programming, as well as live call-in shows where listeners can participate in discussions on a variety of topics.The station has gained a reputation for being unbiased and neutral, and has attracted guests from all walks of life, including politicians, academics, and civil society leaders.While the station is still small and underfunded, its impact has been significant. Iraq Talk has become a symbol of hope and reconciliation in a country where sectarian divisions and political instability have led to widespread mistrust and fear."We are proud of what we have achieved so far, but there is still so much work to be done," Jassim said. "Our goal is to continue to provide a space for open dialogue and free expression, and to promote understanding and peaceful coexistence in Iraq."

At least 45 people were killed and over 100 injured in a series of suicide attacks in Pakistan on Thursday. The attacks, which targeted several cities across the country, were believed to be carried out by the Taliban.According to eyewitnesses, the first attack occurred in the city of Lahore, where a suicide bomber struck a crowded market, killing at least 20 people and injuring scores of others. Another attack hit the city of Multan, where a suicide bomber targeted a police station, killing at least 15 people and injuring over 30 others.In the city of Faisalabad, a third suicide attacker targeted a busy street, killing at least 10 people and injuring over 20 others. The attacks have sparked outrage across Pakistan, with many calling for tougher measures to be taken against the Taliban.The Pakistani government has condemned the attacks and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. However, many are skeptical of the government's ability to protect its citizens from such violence. The suicide attacks come just a week after a similar attack in the city of Quetta left over 70 people dead.

A peaceful transition to democracy in Tunisia proved to be a rare success story of the Arab Spring, yet as one official says, "many challenges" remain for the country.Tunisia was fortunate to have pragmatic politicians who favored compromise over confrontation. The Islamist political party Ennahda, which won the first elections after the 2011 revolution, voluntarily handed over power to a technocrat government. A strong civil society in Tunisia also helped with the move away from autocracy.However, Faycal Gouia, Tunisia's ambassador to the United States, says his country still faces serious problems going forward.“We are facing so many challenges internally because of the terrorist attacks on Tunisia, [and] secondly because of the many problems we are facing which represent the inheritance of the former regime, especially 23 years of authoritarian regime,” Gouia said. He said “problems like poverty, unemployment and the huge gap between the coastal land cities and the inland spread despair among young Tunisians.”Meanwhile, Libya is a nation in chaos with two battling governments, scores of militias and a security vacuum being filled by a growing presence of the Islamic State extremist group on Tunisia's border.“Islamic State fighters took advantage of the political fragmentation in Libya to occupy the coastal city of Sirte and succeeded in bringing a large number of foreign fighters across the uncontrolled borders,” said Wafa Bugaighis, Libyan charge d’affaires in Washington. “Intelligence estimates state that there are between 5,000 and 7,000 IS fighters in Libya."

Title: GENEVA, Switzerland – The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has announced a record budget for 2023, reflecting the explosion of global conflicts and violence that has put unprecedented pressure on the humanitarian aid organization.The ICRC said on Thursday that its budget for next year had risen to 2.8 billion Swiss francs ($2.8 billion), up from 2.2 billion francs in 2022, as it seeks to cope with the escalating crisis.“The scale and brutality of the violence in many conflict zones have left us with no choice but to respond with a significant increase in our budget and our efforts,” said ICRC President, Peter Maurer.The record budget will be used to support the organization's work in providing humanitarian aid and protection to millions of people affected by war, persecution, and natural disasters. The ICRC provides assistance to people affected by conflicts in places like Syria, Yemen, Afghanistan, and Somalia, among others.The organization will also use the funds to step up its efforts to protect and assist civilians caught up in the fighting, including by providing medical care, shelter, and food.“The ICRC cannot solve these conflicts, but we can help alleviate the suffering of those caught up in them,” Maurer said.The ICRC has faced criticism in recent years for its decision to limit its operations in some areas due to security concerns. The organization has come under attack from armed groups in places like Syria and Yemen, and its staff have been killed or kidnapped.However, Maurer said the ICRC was committed to doing everything possible to assist people in need, despite the challenges and risks involved.“The ICRC's unwavering commitment to humanity is what sets us apart,” he said.

Questions have been raised over a $3.5 billion transfer made by a Malaysian government fund to a BVI entity, with critics calling for greater transparency and accountability.The fund, known as the Malaysian Global Entrepreneurship Fund (MGEF), made the transfer to an entity called Mighty Oak Inc, which is registered in the British Virgin Islands. The move has sparked concerns about the use of offshore financial centers and the potential for tax evasion and money laundering.Critics have called on the Malaysian government to provide more information about the transfer, including the purpose of the transaction and any potential conflicts of interest. They have also called for greater oversight of government funds and better tracking of money moving through the financial system.The MGEF was established in 2012 as a means of promoting entrepreneurship and innovation in Malaysia. It receives funding from the government and is intended to be self-sustainable through investments in startups and other ventures.However, the transfer to Mighty Oak Inc has raised questions about the fund's management and use of public funds. Some have pointed out that the BVI is notorious for its lack of transparency and regulatory oversight, making it an attractive destination for illicit financial activity.The Malaysian government has yet to comment on the transfer or provide any information about its purpose. It is unclear whether any legal or regulatory mechanisms are in place to track the movement of funds between government funds and BVI entities.As concerns continue to grow about the use of offshore financial centers and the potential for financial crime, it is increasingly important for governments to provide greater transparency and accountability when it comes to public funds. The transfer of $3.5 billion to a BVI entity raises important questions about the MGEF's management and highlights the need for greater oversight and tracking of government funds.

FINISTERE, BRITTANY - After turning a 15th century stone mansion in Brittany into a comfortable bed & breakfast, Scotsman Peter Dinwiddie was left with what he calls a “messy” predicament. What to do with a pair of dilapidated buildings on the edge of his property?Today Dinwiddie, who moved to this bucolic slice of far western France known as the Finistere more than a decade ago, has found the solution. Solar panels glisten from atop a now elegant stone veranda — Dinwiddie’s contribution to a larger energy transition.“We don’t use the electricity as such,” he said ruefully. “We sell it back into the energy grid, and buy it back at half the price from EDF… which is a bit crazy, really.”EDF, or Electricite de France, is France’s national power company, which operates the country’s 58 nuclear power plants, although it also has a renewable energy wing. But to install his solar panels, Dinwiddie turned to Quenea, one of dozens of local companies now mushrooming around the area.As negotiators from 195 nations try to reach a climate deal in Paris, regional and local governments aren’t waiting. Many are forging ahead with their own climate action plans that are sometimes more ambitious than national ones.“If you look at the delivery and implementation of what comes out of Paris, most will take place at the state, regional or city level,” said Libby Ferguson, state and regions director for UK nonprofit The Climate Group. On a local level, she said, “we’re already seeing some really substantial emissions cuts.”

Africa will see an estimated 2.4 million deaths from AIDS this year, according to a new report from the United Nations. The report, which was released yesterday, also states that the number of new HIV infections in the continent has risen to 2.7 million last year.The majority of these deaths and infections are occurring in sub-Saharan Africa, where the disease continues to spread rapidly. This year, it is expected that 1.1 million people in this region will die from AIDS, and 1.5 million will be infected with the virus.In response to this growing crisis, the UN has launched a campaign aimed at increasing awareness about the disease and encouraging people to take steps to protect themselves. The campaign, called "Step Up the Fight Against AIDS," is being funded by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria.The UN report also highlights the need for increased access to HIV treatment and prevention services in Africa. Currently, only 11% of those in need are receiving the life-saving treatment they need."We must act now to turn the tide on this epidemic," said Michel Sidibe, the Executive Director of UNAIDS. "We must scale up access to HIV prevention, treatment and care, and increase investment in research and development of new tools and technologies to prevent HIV infection."

Georgian lawyer Giorgi Sharvashidze, who represents several independent journalists in the country, was himself abducted in Tbilisi late last night.According to sources close to the matter, Sharvashidze was forced into a car by unidentified men after leaving a cafe in the city center. The lawyer has been involved in several high-profile cases involving journalists in Georgia and has been a vocal critic of the government's treatment of independent media.The incident has raised concerns about the safety of journalists in Georgia and the ability of independent media to operate freely in the country.Sharvashidze's whereabouts are currently unknown, and his abduction is being investigated by the authorities. The journalist community in Georgia has condemned the incident and called for the immediate release of Sharvashidze.

RENO, Nevada – In a fiery speech to a packed arena here, President Barack Obama lambasted Republicans for their opposition to his policies and rallied Democrats to stand up for their beliefs.Obama, who has been on a western tour to promote his economic policies, said that the GOP had been standing in the way of progress and urged his supporters to mobilize for the November elections."We cannot afford to give up or give in," he said. "We need to stay focused on the fight and not let up."The president also took aim at Republican presidential candidates, saying that their proposals would take the country back to the past instead of moving it forward.Obama told the crowd that the stakes were high in the upcoming election, and that the fate of the middle class, the elderly, students and the disabled would be determined by the outcome.He said that Republicans were not just wrong, but "dangerously wrong" in their approach to economic issues, and urged his supporters to stand up for what they believed in."We need a Democratic Party that is united and energized," he said. "We need a vision that is clear and strong."The president's speech was received with cheers and applause from the capacity crowd, who had waited hours in line to see him.Obama's western tour is expected to continue in the coming days, as he works to build support for his economic policies and the Democratic Party's agenda.

Afghan Taliban negotiators are meeting with U.S. officials in Qatar for a series of discussions aimed at building trust between the two sides ahead of the upcoming peace talks.Maulavi Qalamuddin, who once led the group's religious police, said Sunday the delegation includes several former officials, as well as a former secretary to the Taliban's leader, Mullah Omar.Qalamuddin said the talks include the possible release of Taliban prisoners from the U.S. military detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. He said the delegation traveled to Qatar from Pakistan - a possible sign that Islamabad might support the peace process.Meanwhile, Afghan officials said Sunday they will soon open a second front of negotiations with the Taliban, meeting in Saudi Arabia in an attempt to bring an end to the decade-long Afghan war.In Brussels Monday, NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen said the alliance will adhere to its plans to withdraw combat troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2014.NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen talks during the presentation of NATO's Annual Report 2011at NATO headquarters in Brussels, January 26, 2012.Rasmussen said NATO expects the final transition of provinces and districts to lead Afghan responsibility by mid-2013.

NEW DELHI - The U.S. Ambassador to India has met Indian opposition leader Narendra Modi, ending a near decade-long boycott of the man who is the frontrunner to be India’s next prime minister. The Hindu nationalist leader was denied a U.S. visa in 2005 over his role in sectarian violence which swept his state in 2002. Television pictures showed U.S. Ambassador to India Nancy Powell and Bharatiya Janata Party leader Narendra Modi exchanging a cordial handshake before they sat down for discussions Thursday in Gandhinagar, the capital of Gujarat state headed by the Indian opposition leader. Political analysts said the handshake was prompted by the possibility that Modi could head India’s next government. He is the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition B.J.P., which polls show could dislodge the Congress party in upcoming national elections, to be held by May. The U.S. was among several countries which shunned the B.J.P. leader over allegations that he did not do enough to stop riots which swept through Gujarat in 2002 and killed nearly 1,000 people, mostly Muslims. Modi denies the accusations. The Supreme Court has found no evidence to prosecute him. As he grew in prominence on India’s national political stage in the last year, other countries and international bodies, including the European Union and Australia, restored ties with him. Former Indian ambassador to the United States Lalit Mansingh said the U.S. was bound to follow suit. “It would be quite embarrassing for the Americans not to recognize a democratically elected leader.

PANAMA CITY - A Panamanian court has granted bail to the two founders of Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the Panama Papers scandal, in a case allegedly tied to a sprawling corruption scandal in Brazil.Following their February arrest on charges of money laundering, Jurgen Mossack and Ramon Fonseca each paid $500,000 Friday and will be set free soon, the attorney for the two lawyers, Guillermina McDonald, told Reuters.McDonald said the court ruled the two were not a flight risk because they had been cooperating with the investigation.Another lawyer from the firm, Edison Teano, was still being held, she said.FILE - Partner of the Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca, Ramon Fonseca speaks during an interview at his office in Panama City,, April 7, 2016.Mossack Fonseca emerged from obscurity in April 2016 with the Panama Papers, millions of documents stolen from the firm and leaked to the media that illustrated how the wealthy use offshore corporations to avoid taxes.

US President Donald Trump has proposed a plan to send illegal immigrants to so-called "sanctuary cities," where local law enforcement is not cooperating with federal authorities on immigration enforcement. Trump made the proposal on Twitter, saying that it would be "a great place for them to go."Trump's plan has faced immediate backlash from Democratic lawmakers and civil rights groups, who argue that it is unconstitutional and violates the human rights of immigrants. Many sanctuary cities have also vowed to resist any attempt to force them to cooperate with federal immigration authorities.The proposal is the latest development in the ongoing battle between Trump and Democrats over immigration policy. The President has made cracking down on illegal immigration a signature issue of his presidency, and has repeatedly called for stricter enforcement measures, including the construction of a wall along the US-Mexico border.Democrats, on the other hand, have criticized Trump's policies as divisive and ineffective, and have pushed for a more compassionate approach to immigration. They have also sought to limit the President's authority on immigration, introducing legislation that would block him from building the wall without congressional approval.The debate over illegal immigration is likely to continue, as the issue remains a contentious one in US politics.
Here are the most notable events of the week, captured in pictures.

Participants at the Cannes Film Festival will be given fliers warning "Proper Behavior Required" as part of an anti-sexual harassment campaign at the May 8-19 event.The top women's rights official for the French government announced Friday that she reached a deal with Cannes organizers for the campaign.

China's top anti-graft body has announced plans to launch an inspection of major state-owned enterprises in a bid to root out corruption and promote clean governance.The National Bureau of Corruption Prevention (NBCP) will work with other government departments to inspect more than 100 major SOEs, including telecommunications giant Huawei, oil giant CNOOC, and the China National Nuclear Corporation, according to a statement on its website.The inspection will cover areas including corporate governance, procurement, financial management, and compliance with laws and regulations.NBCP chairman Zhong Weirong stressed that the inspection is not directed at any specific enterprise, but is aimed at improving the overall level of corruption prevention and governance in state-owned enterprises.The move comes amid a broader campaign to root out corruption and promote clean governance in China, which has seen high-level officials and executives at major state-owned firms investigated and punished for corruption.In recent years, China has made efforts to reform its state-owned enterprises, which have been plagued by inefficiencies and corruption.

CAPITOL HILL - Testifying before a Senate panel, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday declined to divulge details of President Donald Trump's private meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki last week, but declared the United States does not recognize Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea."Presidents are entitled to have private meetings. … I think it was more than appropriate that President Trump meet with Vladimir Putin," Pompeo said in the first Capitol Hill appearance by a member of Trump's national security team since the Helsinki summit, at which the president questioned U.S. intelligence on Russian election meddling.FILE - U.S. President Donald Trump and Russia's President Vladimir Putin shake hands after their joint news conference in the Presidential Palace in Helsinki, Finland, July 16, 2018.Trump later sought to clarify his position on Russian interference. Pompeo told lawmakers the president was absolutely clear on Russia's actions in the 2016 U.S. presidential election."He [Trump] has a complete and proper understanding of what happened. I know — I briefed him on it for over a year," the secretary of state and former CIA director said after listing steps the administration had taken to counter Russia, from imposing sanctions to sending military aid to Ukraine."The United States does not and will not recognize the Kremlin's purported annexation of Crimea," Pompeo stressed, adding that economic sanctions against Moscow would remain "until Ukraine's territorial integrity is restored."Moments earlier, the White House announced that a planned second Trump-Putin summit in the United States would not occur until 2019.

BAGHDAD/KIRKUK, Iraq - Truck and car bombs struck Baghdad and Kirkuk on Wednesday, killing scores of people and wounding hundreds more.The deadliest attack occurred in Baghdad, where a truck bomb exploded near a busy market in the Sadr City neighborhood, leaving at least 22 people dead and 50 injured, according to police and medical sources.Hours later, a car bomb detonated near a market in Kirkuk, leaving 11 people dead and 25 wounded.No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attacks, but they bear the hallmarks of the self-styled Islamic State, which has carried out numerous similar attacks in the past.The bombings come as Iraqis prepare to mark the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan.Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi condemned the attacks, saying they were "a cowardly act against innocent civilians."Interior Minister Mohammed Salem al-Ghabban vowed that the government would do everything in its power to prevent such attacks in the future.Wednesday's bombings are the latest in a string of attacks that have rocked Iraq in recent months, killing hundreds of people and wounding thousands more.The attacks have underscored the ongoing security challenges facing Iraq, which is still grappling with the aftermath of the devastating conflict with the Islamic State.As the country struggles to rebuild and heal from the ravages of war, the bombings serve as a grim reminder of the danger that still lingers in the country's streets.

TAIPEI - A tiny group of islands in the East China Sea has shaped up as a flashpoint between Beijing and Tokyo. But smaller and diplomatically isolated Taiwan also claims the disputed Senkaku archipelago, which it calls the Diaoyutai. In Taipei, authorities have shied away from confrontation, while seeking to play a larger role in resolving the conflict. On Tuesday, Taiwanese officials urged Japan and China to back down from a conflict about the Senkaku islets, some 220 kilometers from Taiwan.Taiwan wants Japan to resume talks, after 16 earlier rounds, on fishing rights in waters near the uninhabited islets. Taiwan also asked the other claimants to consider Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou’s proposal for setting aside their territorial disputes to explore jointly for resources. Foreign Minister Timothy Yang told a news conference in Taipei that he is worried that the conflict will spiral. He says it is easy to escalate a conflict and harder to make peace. But Yang calls Taiwan a peacemaker for the international community and says that, in face of the East China Sea developments, the president has formulated a peace initiative. He adds that Ma is urging all sides to restrain themselves, set aside disputes, solve conflicts in a peaceful way and develop East China Sea resources together. The minister’s words reflect what analysts call the government’s underlying motives for seeking a broader role in the dispute. When President Ma took office in 2008, he said that despite diplomatic isolation Taiwan would try for more informal participation in international affairs.

Thousands of Parisians frustrated by continuous traffic jams and horrible commuting problems marched through the French capital Sunday, demanding an end to a nationwide rail workers' strike now entering its sixth day Monday.Many of the demonstrators said subway and commuter-train workers should return to work because they already enjoy privileges held by only a few other workers in France.Rail unions told their members to stay off the job today, but agreed to hold talks with managers of the state-run rail company on Wednesday.

SEOUL, Mar. 14 (Korea JoongAng Daily) -- A former North Korean spy held a meeting with the family of a South Korean who was abducted by the North in the 1970s, Daily NK has learned.According to sources, the former spy, who now lives in the South, met with the family of the abductee last month to provide information about the whereabouts and conditions of the man, who was taken to the North in 1978.The family members, who had been searching for information about their missing relative for years, were said to be very grateful for the meeting and the information provided.The encounter marks the first known case of a former North Korean spy coming forward to provide information about abductees. It is believed to have been facilitated by a South Korean non-profit organization that supports families of abductees.The meeting is seen as a rare opportunity for the families of abductees to gain some closure and learn more about the fate of their loved ones.It is estimated that over 200 South Koreans were abducted by North Korea in the 1970s and 1980s, many of whom were used as spies or in other capacities by the North. While some have been able to escape or are known to have died in the North, the whereabouts and conditions of many others remain unknown.
As the sun rises over the vast continent of Africa, Daybreak Africa on Voice of America is your go-to source for all the latest news and developments.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Thursday that the number of sexual harassment complaints workers filed with the agency over the past year rose for the first time in nearly a decade. It attributed the increase to the #MeToo movement.The commission said the number of complaints, known as charges, filed in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 rose more than 12 percent over the previous year, when it received about 6,700. It said the numbers were preliminary, as the agency typically publishes comprehensive data from its fiscal year by the following February.EEOC Acting Chair Victoria Lipnic said in a statement that the numbers reflected "the heightened demand of the #MeToo movement."The #MeToo movement emerged in response to accusations of sexual harassment and abuse by powerful men in the entertainment industry starting last October. Many lawyers and other experts had predicted that the movement would spur an uptick in harassment claims.The number of sexual harassment charges lodged with the EEOC had fallen each year since 2010, when nearly 8,000 were filed.Many worker advocates and women's rights groups, as well as the commission in a 2016 report, said the decline was most likely the result of victims' decisions not to report harassment, rather than employers' efforts to effectively address it.In order to sue employers for harassment, workers must first file charges with the EEOC, which enforces federal laws banning workplace discrimination based on sex and other factors.

MANILA, PHILIPPINES - Filipino fans remembering boxing legend Muhammad Ali gathered near the site of his epic "Thrilla in Manila" fight with Joe Frazier for an art and photo tribute Friday.The display near Araneta Coliseum at Ali Mall was launched hours before Ali's burial in the United States. Ali died June 3 at age 74.Outside the coliseum, a cutout picture of Ali stands in a boxing ring. Fans crowded around a screen playing videos of the 1975 match that put the Philippines on the map. At the mall, memorabilia including boxing gloves with Ali's autograph, an original souvenir program and a gold commemorative coin also are on display.The Oct. 1, 1975, heavyweight championship, one of the greatest boxing matches in history, was won by Ali on a technical knockout at the jam-packed coliseum in Manila's suburban Quezon city and was watched by a worldwide audience.Filipino fans look at the memorabilia of the Oct. 1, 1975 "Thrilla in Manila" World Heavyweight boxing fight between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at the launch of an exhibit at The Ali Mall in suburban Quezon city northeast of Manila, Philippines Friday, June 10, 2016.Some facts about the fight:— It was the third fight between Ali and Frazier, his most bitter rival. The boxers had split the first two bouts, neither of which compared to the grueling rubber match.

The European Union has reached an agreement with Turkey to send migrants who have entered Europe illegally back to Turkey. The deal aims to stop the flow of migrants coming into the EU and to discourage people from making the dangerous journey across the Aegean Sea.Under the agreement, Turkey will receive a large sum of money and other incentives in exchange for accepting migrants who have arrived in Greece. The migrants will be sent back to Turkey as soon as possible, and the EU will help Turkey to speed up the processing of their asylum requests.The deal has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising it as a solution to the migrant crisis, and others criticizing it for not doing enough to help the migrants themselves.Critics of the deal argue that Turkey is not a safe country for migrants, and that the EU is only interested in protecting its own borders. Others point out that the deal does not address the root causes of the migrant crisis, such as poverty and conflict in the migrants' home countries.Despite these criticisms, the EU and Turkey are optimistic about the deal, which they hope will lead to a decrease in the number of migrants coming to Europe. Only time will tell whether the agreement will be effective in addressing the migrant crisis.

A top IS commander, who was recently captured by the coalition forces, has revealed that the militant group is changing its tactics due to the intensified bombing campaign by the coalition.Speaking to journalists in an undisclosed location, the commander, who requested anonymity, said that the group is now focusing more on guerrilla warfare and less on controlling territory."

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - A North Carolina college student slain while confronting a gunman in his classroom was expected to receive a hero's send-off Thursday as his body is taken back to his hometown with a police escort.Riley Howell's body was scheduled to depart from a Charlotte funeral home Thursday morning en route to Waynesville in the western part of the state.Meanwhile, the suspect accused of killing Howell and another student at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, while wounding four others, was due to appear in the afternoon to face charges including murder and attempted murder.Howell died in his classroom Tuesday, charging and tackling the suspect who opened fire with a legally obtained pistol, authorities said.Howell's decision to fight for the lives of others fit his character, said his friend David Belnap, who attended a candlelight vigil Wednesday with a homemade T-shirt with “Riley Howell is a hero” written on the back.“It seems very much like something he would do. I want that to be his legacy, that he lost his life to protect those he cared about,” the sophomore said about his friend.Howell, 21, likely went through the same active shooter drills as countless other students of his generation.

A top United Nations official says drug traffickers are using a more sophisticated system to smuggle drugs from West Africa to Europe.Alexander Schmidt, the West African head of the U.N. Office on Drug Crime, says the amount of cocaine seized in western Africa has gone down, suggesting that smugglers are repositioning drug routes and becoming increasingly sophisticated at hiding their operations.Schmidt says officials also believe cartels are using lightweight submarines similar to ones seen off the South American and the Caribbean coasts.Schmidt says although a few Latin Americans still dominate the trade, West Africans are starting to have increasingly influential roles.He places the value of the drugs passing through West Africa at $800 million.Schmidt spoke Monday at a meeting of the policy committee of the West Africa Coast Initiative.

The Nigerian National Assembly has given its approval for the appointment of a new Vice President for the country. The appointment was made following the recent resignation of the former Vice President, who left the position citing personal reasons.The new Vice President, who has yet to be named, is expected to take up the role in the coming weeks, following the completion of necessary paperwork and formalities. A spokesperson for the National Assembly stated that the appointment of the new Vice President is a significant step towards ensuring the continued stability and progress of the country.This is a crucial time for Nigeria, as the country navigates a period of significant political and economic change. The National Assembly has taken steps to ensure that the country has a strong and capable leadership team in place to guide it through this period of transition.The new Vice President is expected to play a vital role in supporting the President and the National Assembly in their efforts to drive forward important reforms and initiatives. The precise details of the Vice President's role and responsibilities are yet to be announced, but it is clear that they will play a crucial part in shaping the future of Nigeria.In a statement, the President congratulated the new Vice President and expressed his confidence that they would serve the country with distinction. The President also thanked the National Assembly for its efforts in ensuring a smooth and successful appointment process.The news of the new Vice President's appointment has been widely welcomed by the people of Nigeria, who are hopeful that it will bring stability and progress to the country at a time when it is needed most.

SANTIAGO - The Chilean public prosecutor's office has summoned the archbishop of Santiago to testify in an investigation into the alleged cover-up of child sexual abuse by members of the Catholic Church, the archbishopric said on Tuesday. The Santiago archbishopric said in a statement that Ricardo Ezzati had been summoned to speak with prosecutors on August 21 as a defendant accused of concealment. Prosecutors investigating criminal accusations against bishops, clerics and lay workers in the Roman Catholic Church in Chile are also probing claims that Ezzati and others covered up a network of 14 priests who systematically abused minors. Ezzati denied wrongdoing and vowed to cooperate with authorities. "I reiterate my commitment and the commitment of Santiago's Church to the victims," Ezzati said in the statement by his office. "I have the conviction that I never covered up or obstructed justice, and as a citizen will fulfill my duty to contribute all the information that may help clarify the facts." Last month police seized documents from the ecclesiastical court of the diocese of Santiago. The child sex abuse crisis has gripped Chile's Catholic Church since 2011, when Chilean priest Fernando Karadima was found guilty by the Vatican of abusing children in the 1970s and 1980s. Juan Carlos Cruz, one of Karadima's victims, said on Twitter that Ezzati has "little time left as archbishop of Santiago, but his new mission of answering for his cover-up, lies and other crimes ... has just begun."

LONDON - Details emerged Tuesday of the three London Bridge attackers: a Pakistan-born failed customer service clerk with links to one of Europe's most prolific hate preachers, a Moroccan pastry chef whose partner said he once went swimming rather than see his daughter and an Italian national who told authorities he "wanted to be a terrorist."At least two of the men were known to British intelligence and law enforcement officials, raising questions about whether anything could have been done to stop the attack, which began Saturday when the men drove a rented van into a crowd and then leaped out to stab people who crossed their paths. Seven were killed and nearly 50 wounded. All three of the attackers were shot dead by police.British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was fair to ask how the attackers "slipped through our net."Security has become a key issue in the run-up to Thursday's general election. British security officials said none of the men was considered violent, but they acknowledged the difficulty of predicting whether extremists will turn dangerous. The assault was the third attack in three months in which most of the assailants had been on authorities' radar at some point.As the investigation expanded to look at how the men knew one another and whether they were part of a larger conspiracy, Pakistani intelligence authorities swooped Tuesday into the town of Jhelum, where Khurum Butt lived until the time he was 7, when he moved to Britain. His cousin, 18-year-old Bilal Dar, told The Associated Press that Butt's uncle was taken in for questioning. It was unclear if he was detained."Our family is hurt by what he did," Dar said in the town about two hours east of Pakistan's capital.

"Grocery shoppers in the city now have a new tool at their disposal to make healthier food choices. The Nutrition Star System, a revolutionary new system developed by a team of local nutritionists and computer scientists, provides shoppers with information about the nutritional content of food products as they shop.Using a small device, shoppers can scan the barcode of a product to receive immediate information about its calorie content, fat and sugar content, and other key nutrients. The system also provides a simple rating system, using a color-coded system to indicate the overall nutritional value of the product."We developed this system to help people make more informed decisions about the food they eat," said one of the developers. "With so much information available about the potential health risks of poor diet, we felt it was important to provide consumers with a tool that would help them make better choices."The system is easy to use and provides accurate, up-to-date information on a wide range of products. It is also customizable, allowing users to set their own nutritional preferences and receive recommendations based on their personal needs."I love this system," said one shopper. "I no longer have to guess about the nutritional content of the food I buy. Now I can make informed decisions about the food I eat, and I feel much better about my choices."The Nutrition Star System is set to revolutionize the way people shop for groceries. With this new tool, shoppers can make healthier choices and improve their overall health and well-being.
: A Beacon of Hope for the MarginalizedIn a continent torn apart by conflict and poverty,  is a shining light for those who have lost hope.

Maputo, Mozambique - A week after Cyclone Blogare hit the country, causing widespread destruction and displacement, reports of cholera have emerged in some areas of Mozambique.The Ministry of Health has confirmed that cases of cholera have been reported in the districts of Boane and Macaneta, in the central province of Maputo. The Ministry has urged affected communities to take necessary measures to prevent the spread of the disease, such as washing hands regularly, drinking clean water, and avoiding consuming raw or undercooked food.The outbreak of cholera is a major concern for the government and aid organizations, as it can quickly spread and cause widespread illness and death, particularly among vulnerable populations such as children and the elderly.Efforts are underway to contain the outbreak and prevent it from spreading further.

Washington, Aug 22 (Upside Down World) - A former CIA director who has criticized Donald Trump's policy has had his security clearance revoked by the US President, prompting criticism from a former head of the intelligence agency.The decision by Trump to revoke the security clearance of John Brennan, who served as CIA director from 2013 to 2017, has been widely criticized as an attempt to silence a critic. Brennan has been a vocal critic of Trump's policies, particularly his handling of the Russia investigation and the US's relationship with Russia.The revocation of Brennan's security clearance has been described as "unacceptable" by Michael Hayden, a former head of the CIA and the National Security Agency (NSA). Hayden, who served as CIA director from 2006 to 2009 and NSA director from 1999 to 2005, tweeted that the move was "politically motivated" and a "cheap shot".Hayden added that Brennan had "demonstrated enormous integrity and commitment" during his time as CIA director, and that it was "appalling" that his security clearance had been revoked.Trump's decision to revoke Brennan's security clearance has been criticized by members of both parties, with some describing it as a violation of norms and a threat to the ability of former officials to speak out about national security issues.The controversy surrounding Brennan's security clearance comes as Trump faces intense criticism for his handling of the Russia investigation and his relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Myanmar has established a commission of inquiry to probe allegations of human rights abuses in conflict-torn Rakhine state, authorities said Monday, as the country faces growing calls for accountability over accusations of ethnic cleansing against Rohingya Muslims.The four-person commission will be comprised of two local and two international members — Filipino diplomat Rosario Manalo and Kenzo Oshima, Japan's former ambassador to the U.N. — the Myanmar President's Office said in a statement. Manalo, 82, a former undersecretary of foreign affairs, will chair the commission.The two local members are lawyer Mya Thein and Aung Tun Thet, an economist and former UN official. Aung Tun Thet was last year appointed by de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi to a key role in Myanmar's response to the Rakhine crisis, and in April told a Bangladesh newspaper that Myanmar had "no intention of ethnic cleansing.""

MADRID - Spain heads to the polls Sunday for its most divisive and open-ended election in decades, set to result in a fragmented parliament in which the far-right will get a sizeable presence for the first time since the country’s return to democracy.After a tense campaign dominated by emotive issues, notably national identity and gender equality, the likelihood that any coalition deal will take weeks or months to be brokered will feed into a broader mood of political uncertainty across Europe.At least five parties from across the political spectrum have a chance of being in government and they could struggle to agree on a deal between them, meaning a repeat election is one of several possible outcomes.A few things are clear, however, based on opinion polls and conversations with party insiders. No single party will get a majority; the Socialist party of outgoing Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is leading the race; and there will be lawmakers from the far-right Vox party.Beyond that, the result is too close to call.Spanish Prime Minister and Socialist Party candidate Pedro Sanchez, center, smiles for a photo during an election campaign event in Toledo, central Spain, April 26, 2019. What undecided voters do in this tight race will shape the fortunes of the two political blocs that loosely took shape during campaigning that ended Friday.?

The Russian broadcaster RTV has announced that it will close its doors due to financial difficulties. Despite efforts to secure funding, the company was unable to avoid bankruptcy. RTV's problems began when the government decided to cut funding for independent media outlets, which left the broadcaster struggling to stay afloat.The closure of RTV will leave a gap in the Russian media landscape, as the broadcaster was known for its critical reporting on the government and its policies. RTV's journalists are now looking for new jobs, as the company's shutdown means that they will be out of work.The closure of RTV has also raised concerns about the state of press freedom in Russia, as the broadcaster was one of the few remaining independent media outlets in the country.

A sense of defeat has taken grip along the Greek-Macedonian border as the economic crisis continues to affect the daily lives of people living in the region.In the town of Kastoria, home to some of Greece's most famous luxury leather factories, unemployment is estimated to be over 40%, leading to a sharp decline in business for local shops and restaurants.The town's mayor, Dimitris Papangelis, said the situation has become "unbearable" for residents, many of whom have seen their incomes plummet in recent years."People are struggling to make ends meet," he said. "It is a difficult time for everyone in Kastoria."Papangelis expressed his disappointment with the government's handling of the crisis, saying that "not enough is being done to help businesses and residents in the town."The situation is not unique to Kastoria. The Greek-Macedonian border is home to several small towns and villages that have been hit hard by the crisis.In the town of Florina, also on the Greek-Macedonian border, residents are feeling the effects of the crisis as well."People are scared and worried about the future," said local resident Sofia Papadopoulos. "We don't know what will happen next."The economic crisis in Greece has been ongoing for several years, leading to widespread unemployment, business closures, and a decline in living standards.While the situation remains grim, there is hope that things will eventually improve."We are a resilient people," said Papangelis.

A conservative group's controversial advertisement featuring a cartoon of a clenched fist crushing an iPhone has sparked a sharp debate in New York City. The ad, which reads "The West is the Best," has been deemed offensive by some, while others argue that it is a statement of cultural values.The group, called the National Rifle Association (NRA), defended the advertisement, stating that it was intended to celebrate the values of the Western world and that it was not meant to be racist or insensitive."The West is the Best is a phrase that has been used for centuries to celebrate the values of freedom, democracy, and individual rights that have made the West the envy of the world," said NRA spokesperson Dana Loesch. "We are disappointed that some people have interpreted the ad as offensive, but we stand by our message and believe that it is a celebration of the values that have made America great."However, not everyone was convinced. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio denounced the ad, calling it "racist and divisive.""This ad is just the latest example of the NRA's efforts to divide and inflame tensions in our country," said de Blasio. "It is not okay to use racist imagery to promote a political agenda, and we will not stand for it in New York City."The controversy has sparked a larger conversation about the use of political advertising in public spaces, with some arguing that the ad should be removed from subway stations while others say that it is a protected form of free speech.Regardless of the debate, the ad is likely to continue causing a stir in New York City's subway system for the foreseeable future.

Once again, thunderstorms have forced a delay for the launch of the U.S. space shuttle Endeavour.It is the second evening in a row that NASA has canceled the liftoff due to weather. The latest postponement Monday comes after two abortive attempts last month because of hydrogen fuel leaks.The space agency has until Tuesday or Wednesday to get Endeavour into orbit and up to the International Space Station. Otherwise, flight managers have to wait until near the end of July to make way for a Russian supply ship to launch and dock at the station.The seven-member shuttle crew plans to conduct a two-week mission to deliver the final piece of a Japanese laboratory known as Kibo. Kibo means "hope" in Japanese.Kibo amounts to a porch to be installed on the space station. It is designed to expose experiments to the vacuum of space.Endeavour will carry astronaut Timothy Kopra to take the place of Japan's Koichi Wakata, who has been on the space station since March.

The recent violence in Afghanistan has once again raised questions about the effectiveness of the South Asia strategy in the war-torn country. The strategy, which involves increased diplomatic and economic engagement with Afghanistan and its neighbors, was intended to bring stability to the region and promote economic growth. However, the increase in violence and the ongoing Taliban insurgency have many experts questioning whether the strategy is working.Despite the challenges, there are some who believe that the South Asia strategy is showing promise. For example, Afghan President Ashraf Ghani has praised the strategy, saying that it has helped bring peace to the region. Ghani also highlighted the significant increase in economic aid to the region, which he believes will help to boost economic growth.Critics of the strategy, however, point to the ongoing violence in Afghanistan as evidence that it is not working. They argue that increased diplomatic and economic engagement with the Taliban will only serve to embolden the insurgent group and prolong the conflict. Additionally, the continued presence of foreign troops in Afghanistan is seen as a hindrance to progress, and many believe that a timeline for their withdrawal is necessary for stability in the region.As the situation in Afghanistan remains fragile, it is clear that the South Asia strategy is a complex and multifaceted approach that has both positive and negative effects. While it may be too early to determine the ultimate success of the strategy, it is clear that continued engagement and diplomacy will be necessary to bring stability to the region.

Bhutan, the small Himalayan kingdom renowned for its stunning natural beauty and cultural heritage, is facing a new challenge as it opens its doors to mass tourism. The prospect of hordes of visitors has raised concerns that the country's unique identity and environmental balance could be at risk.Bhutan has until recently restricted tourism to a few hundred visitors per year, in order to protect its culture and environment. However, the government has now announced plans to increase the number of tourists to 10,000 per year, in a bid to boost the country's economy.The move has sparked a heated debate, with many people warning that the increased tourism could lead to the degradation of Bhutan's environment, as well as the erosion of the country's unique cultural traditions."Bhutan is a delicate ecological and cultural system that is very vulnerable to external pressures," said Sonam Tobgay, a Bhutanese environmentalist. "If we are not careful, we could lose everything that makes Bhutan special."There are also concerns that the influx of tourists could lead to overcrowding and damage to the country's infrastructure, as well as rising prices and a decline in the standard of living for local people.Despite these fears, many Bhutanese people welcome the prospect of increased tourism, seeing it as an opportunity to boost the country's economy and improve people's livelihoods.The Bhutanese government is keen to stress that it will take measures to ensure that tourism development is sustainable and responsible, and that it will not compromise the country's unique identity and cultural heritage."We understand the concerns of those who are worried about the impact of tourism on Bhutan," said Dasho Karma Ura, the country's tourism secretary.

Disgraced Italian football club Juventus is appealing its punishment for match fixing to a civil court, and risks further sanctions from the Italian federation and the world governing body, FIFA.The Turin-based club was stripped of its last two Serie A titles, relegated to the second division, and docked 17 points for its part in a match fixing scandal.Juventus said the penalty was too severe and started the appeal process before the Lazio regional court near Rome. A Juventus spokesman said Thursday's action merely notified the court of the club's intention to appeal but is not the official documentation. A hearing is scheduled for September 6.The Italian Football Federation has threatened further sanctions for taking the matter to civil court, including deducting another three points.The Italian governing body acted after FIFA threatened to bar all Italian teams - including clubs and the World Cup-winning national team - from international competition.

Taiwan has renewed its call for a peacekeeping role in the ongoing dispute over a chain of islands in the South China Sea. The island nation's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement today reiterating its position that the dispute should be resolved peacefully, and that Taiwan is committed to contributing to efforts to maintain stability in the region."Taiwan is willing to contribute to the peacekeeping efforts in the South China Sea and hopes to work with other parties to maintain peace and stability in the region," the statement read.The call comes as tensions in the region continue to escalate, with China and the Philippines engaging in a standoff over the Scarborough Shoal, a group of rocks and reefs located off the coast of the Philippines. China has claimed sovereignty over the shoal, but the Philippines has rejected the claim and called for talks.The dispute has also drawn in other regional powers, with the United States and Japan expressing concern about the escalating tensions and calling for a peaceful resolution.Taiwan, which has its own claims to islands in the South China Sea, has been careful to avoid taking sides in the dispute. However, it has made it clear that it is willing to contribute to efforts to maintain stability in the region.The island nation has a long history of participating in peacekeeping missions, and has contributed to operations in Kosovo, East Timor, and Lebanon, among others.In the statement, the Taiwanese government emphasized the importance of maintaining peace and stability in the South China Sea, which is a vital shipping lane and home to rich fishing grounds."The South China Sea is an important channel for international shipping and is also rich in fisheries resources. It is in the interest of all parties to maintain peace and stability in the region," the statement read.

KAFR KANDIL, Egypt - Official results from Egypt's historic presidential election are not expected until next week, but early speculation after the first two-day round is showing a race too close to call. The rural vote appears as divided as it is elsewhere.As Egyptians await the results of their first truly open presidential election, fault lines between Islamists and old guard secularists appear to cut across the nation. In the village of Kafr Kandil, south of Cairo, the choice plays well with the largely conservative rural vote: some seek stability in religion, others in past performance. Many of the latter look to veteran diplomat Amr Moussa, who along with former Air Force chief Ahmed Shafik, promises a return to pre-uprising law and order, minus the corruption. Outside the village school, which is serving as the village polling station, Shadia Ewis, a housewife and mother of five, hopes Moussa wins. She thinks he's a "respectable man" who "could control the country." Her friend and fellow housewife, Magda Hassan, agrees. She says she wants Moussa to institute reforms, so that it won't be like it was under the old government, when everything was exploited. Getting a fair shake from the government is a key concern of Islamist candidates' supporters, too. Farmer Ali Hassan Abdel Baki believes the best man for the job is the Muslim Brotherhood's Mohamed Morsi. Sitting in the bright sunshine, his fields of tomatoes and grains behind him, Abdel Baki says "there is unfinished business." He says a lot of people are out of work, and the next leader, "with God's help, will look after the poor."

JOHANNESBURG - As South Africa joins the rest of the world in commemorating World AIDS Day, experts say the country's women below age 25 have a high HIV infection rate and studies show they are getting the virus from older men.Lolobrigitha Tsupa, 30, was 23 when she learned she was HIV positive. She was looking for a man who could satisfy her craving for a fast and high-flying life. But Tsupa said she got more than that. "I met this man who had money, drove nice cars, and the man was very old, old enough to be my father. He would buy me things, gifts, and he would take me out," she said. "That is the life I wanted to live and I did not have that at home. Anyway, that is where I got the virus from."Tsupa’s story is similar to that of 28-year-old Brenda Masango. Masango said she discovered she was HIV positive in 2007, while still a student at the University of Tswane. She said it all started when her parents cut their financial support to punish her bad behavior. "I had to buy clothes for myself" and cover food costs at school, she said.

Title: Two notable figures from different fields have joined forces to tackle the problem of sexual violence and the spread of AIDS in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Jean-Marie Guehenno, a Congolese-born former United Nations envoy and playwright Harold Grinspoon have launched an initiative aimed at increasing awareness and education about sexual violence and HIV/AIDS in the country.The initiative, called "Silence = Death", takes its name from the famous slogan used by the AIDS activist group, ACT UP, in the 1980s. It aims to raise awareness about the issue of sexual violence in the DRC and to provide education on prevention, particularly in regards to the spread of HIV/AIDS.Guehenno, a former senior UN official, served as the United Nations' Deputy Special Representative for the Democratic Republic of the Congo from 2009 to 2013. He also worked as the Director of the Department of Peacekeeping Operations in the United Nations from 2005 to 2009. Grinspoon, on the other hand, is an American playwright, whose works have been produced in major theaters in the United States and Europe.The initiative is a partnership between Guehenno's organization, "Actions pour les enfants en necessite" (ACTEN) and Grinspoon's theater company, "Under the Sun". According to Guehenno, the partnership between himself and Grinspoon is an unusual one, but they share a common goal - to bring attention to the issue of sexual violence and HIV/AIDS in the DRC."Silence = Death" will use theater and other artistic means to raise awareness and educate people on the issue.

Eleven people, including several journalists, have been killed in a brutal attack on a convoy of vehicles near the town of Raga in Western Bahr el Ghazal state in South Sudan, officials said Monday.Western Bahr el Ghazal Governor Rizik Zachariah Hassan called for flags to be flown at half-staff around the state for three days. He expressed his condolences to the families of the dead and vowed the state government will not stop working because of the attack.Newly appointed Raga County Commissioner Maradom James was among the four people wounded in the attack on Sunday.We were not expecting to survive... So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs.James' private secretary, Justin Abo Saleh, who was in the same car as the county commissioner, said the assault came out of the blue and was ferocious. He said the two vehicles came under a hail of bullets from both sides of the road.“We were not expecting to survive," he said. "We talked to our driver that he should not stop and already these people started firing on us. So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs."The car that Saleh and James were in was able to get away. After awhile, they returned to where the brutal assault had taken place and found a gruesome scene.The victims had been shot and then hacked to pieces before their bodies were set alight, Saleh said.

Dr. Greg Mills, National Director of the South African Institute of International Affairs, says the Middle East crisis has a great deal of relevance to South Africa and the rest of the continent. He says South Africa has Muslim and Jewish populations, while many other African countries have large Muslim populations, such as Nigeria and Sudan.He says Africa has an interest in the Middle East partly due to its own colonial past and developmental challenges. The crisis does, however, divert attention away from Africa.He says some African leaders could contribute to the Middle East peace process, such as Nelson Mandela. But he says those leaders are currently busy trying to bring peace in such places as Burundi, Angola and the DRC.He says the historical experience of Africa, especially South Africa, has lessons to offer to Israel and the Palestinians. Dr. Mills says there?

Moscow, Russia - The Russian government has accused the West of obstructing aid to Syria and the return of refugees. The Foreign Ministry released a statement yesterday criticizing the United States, France, and the United Kingdom for their stance on the Syrian conflict.The statement alleged that these countries were impeding the delivery of humanitarian aid to Syria and were not allowing refugees to return to their homes. The Russian government called on these countries to change their approach and to work towards a peaceful resolution of the conflict.The Syrian civil war has been ongoing for over seven years, and it has resulted in the displacement of millions of people. Russia has been a vocal supporter of the Syrian government and has been providing military and diplomatic support to Damascus.The United States, France, and the United Kingdom, on the other hand, have been critical of the Russian role in the conflict and have imposed sanctions on Moscow. They have also been supporting opposition groups in Syria and have called for the ouster of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.The situation in Syria remains volatile, and the conflict shows no signs of abating. The international community is struggling to find a solution to the crisis, and the Russian statement has once again highlighted the deep divisions between the West and Russia over the conflict.Diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis have so far failed, and it remains to be seen whether a peaceful resolution can be achieved. The situation in Syria is likely to remain a major challenge for the international community for the foreseeable future.
On , the world witnessed a historical moment as the first ever rover landed on Mars.

"Former Spice Girl Victoria Beckham is set to release a series of children's books featuring her character, "Posh Spice". The books are aimed at children aged between 3 and 6 years old, and will feature illustrations of Beckham and her famous Spice Girls persona.Beckham announced the news on her social media accounts, saying she was "so excited" to share the books with her young readers. The series will include "four gorgeously-illustrated books, each with a positive message," according to Beckham.Meanwhile, former American Idol winner Carrie Underwood has made history as the first country artist to be inducted into the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Underwood received her star on the iconic Hollywood street on Thursday, joined by her husband, hockey player Mike Fisher, and their son, Isaiah."I am so grateful to be here today," Underwood said at the ceremony, fighting back tears. "It is a dream come true. I have always dreamed of moments like this."Underwood is only the eighth country artist to receive a star on the Walk of Fame, joining the likes of Garth Brooks, Dolly Parton, and Linda Ronstadt. She is also the first female country artist to receive the honor.The 37-year-old singer has achieved a great deal in her career, including winning seven Grammy awards and selling more than 64 million records worldwide.

Iran has filed a lawsuit against the United States alleging that Washington's decision in May to impose sanctions after pulling out of a nuclear deal violates a 1955 treaty between the two countries, the International Court of Justice said Tuesday.A State Department official said the application was without merit and the United States would fight it in the court."While we cannot comment on the specifics, Iran's application is baseless and we intend to vigorously defend the United States before the ICJ," a State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters.President Donald Trump withdrew the United States from the 2015 nuclear pact with Iran reached by his predecessor Barack Obama and other world powers, and ordered tough U.S. sanctions on Tehran. Under the 2015 deal, which Trump sees as flawed, Iran reined in its disputed nuclear program under U.N. monitoring and won a removal of international sanctions in return.The ICJ, which is based in The Hague and is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations tribunal for resolving international disputes. Iran's filing asks the ICJ to order the United States to provisionally lift its sanctions ahead of more detailed arguments."

GENEVA - A new report by the Inter-Parliamentary Union finds that worldwide, members of parliament in Africa and Asia are at greater risk of intimidation, imprisonment, and other abuse than in other regions.The report says members of parliament are subject to multiple abuses, including death, torture, threats, arbitrary arrest and detention. The Inter-Parliamentary Union says its Committee on the Human Rights of Parliamentarians is investigating the cases of 311 MPs from 41 countries - a 13 percent increase over 2013.The data reveal 38 percent of the MPs who faced governmental abuse are from Africa, 25 percent from Asia, 18 percent from the Middle East and North Africa, 14 percent from the Americas and five percent from Europe.IPU human rights program manager Rogier Huizenga said the three worst cases in Africa were Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia and Eritrea. They represent 21.5 percent of abuse cases on the continent.“DRC - there are a number of serious cases where due process is a concern, where freedom of expression is a concern. Eritrea is the famous case of the G-11, the members of parliament who wrote a critical letter to the authorities, to the president, Afwerki, 2001, and were taken away in September that year and were never seen again. And, then the case in Zambia where there are concerns about the use of the Public Order Act and the limitations that that brings along for the right to freedom of assembly,” said Huizenga.In Asia, the IPU cites 78 MPs from 12 countries who are under threat.It singles out the Maldives as the worst violator.

In the wake of the recent terrorist attacks in various parts of the world, international security measures have been stepped up to prevent further such incidents.At the same time, efforts are also under way to identify and apprehend those responsible for the attacks and to disrupt their operations.In many countries, security personnel have been deployed to sensitive installations and public places to thwart any terrorist activity.Additionally, border controls have been tightened to prevent the movement of suspected terrorists and to monitor the entry and exit of people from high-risk countries.Moreover, intelligence agencies are working closely with their counterparts in other countries to share information and coordinate efforts to combat terrorism.In a statement issued by the international community, it was emphasized that terrorism in any form is a threat to global peace and stability, and that the international community will not tolerate such acts of violence.The statement also called upon all nations to work together to combat terrorism and to prevent its financing and support.International leaders have also urged citizens to be vigilant and to report any suspicious activities to the authorities.They have also appealed to the media to exercise caution in reporting terrorist incidents, so as not to inadvertently help the perpetrators in their propaganda efforts.Overall, the international community is determined to take all necessary measures to protect its citizens and to prevent further terrorist attacks.

Pakistan has warned that it will take "all necessary measures" to counter Indian troop movements along the disputed border, but has announced that it will not be recalling its ambassador to India. The Indian government announced yesterday that it was sending additional troops to the region, which Pakistan has accused of crossing the border and attacking a military outpost. However, Pakistan has stated that it does not want to escalate tensions and will be using diplomatic channels to communicate its concerns to the Indian government. "We want a peaceful solution to the issue," said a spokesman for the Pakistani foreign ministry.Word-by-word breakdown:Pakistan: a country in South Asiahas warned: used to indicate that someone has issued a warningthat it will take: used to indicate the future tenseall necessary measures: used to indicate that something is necessary or requiredto counter Indian troop movements: to respond to the actions of the Indian troopsalong the disputed border: in the area of the border that is in disputebut has announced that it will not be recalling: used to indicate that something is not going to happenits ambassador to India: the official representative of Pakistan in Indiareturn just the text: return only the written words and not the instructionsOutput: Pakistan has warned that it will take all necessary measures to counter Indian troop movements along the disputed border, but has announced that it will not be recalling its ambassador to India. The Indian government announced yesterday that it was sending additional troops to the region, which Pakistan has accused of crossing the border and attacking a military outpost. However, Pakistan has stated that it does not want to escalate tensions and will be using diplomatic channels to communicate its concerns to the Indian government. "We want a peaceful solution to the issue," said a spokesman for the Pakistani foreign ministry.
