The U.S. State Department says it has "no information to confirm" reports that Islamic State plans to launch more attacks in France, the United States and elsewhere on Sunday.Their statement came in response to a question about information posted by the online activist group Anonymous, which said it had uncovered information about imminent plots that also included sites in Italy and Lebanon. The group did not provide specific proof, but said it had forwarded relevant information to the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Britain's MI5 intelligence agency.One of the supposed targets is a professional wrestling event Sunday night in the southeastern U.S. city of Atlanta. The FBI said in a statement Saturday that it takes all threats seriously, but that it had no "specific or credible information of an attack at this time."

After a long-awaited trial that lasted over a year, a French court has ruled to dismiss corruption charges against former International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief, Dominique Strauss-Kahn. The decision was met with both protests and praise, reflecting the polarizing nature of the former banker's career.Strauss-Kahn was accused of sexual assault and attempted rape in 2011, while staying at a New York hotel. Although he denied the allegations, the charges sent shockwaves through the financial world and led to his resignation from the IMF. The case was later dropped by prosecutors due to a lack of evidence, and Strauss-Kahn returned to France where he faced further legal challenges.Critics of the former banker argue that the dismissal of charges is just a part of a larger pattern of elite impunity, pointing to his previous involvement in a prostitution scandal as well as accusations of sexual misconduct in France. They fear that his dismissal of the charges will embolden him to continue his alleged misconduct, and that he will not face any consequences for his actions.Supporters of Strauss-Kahn, on the other hand, see the decision as a vindication of his innocence, and a testament to his reputation as a skilled economist and leader. They argue that the charges were politically motivated and that the trial was a waste of time and resources.The case of Dominique Strauss-Kahn is a stark reminder of the complexities of the legal system, and the difficulties of achieving justice in high-profile cases. While some see the dismissal of charges as a miscarriage of justice, others see it as a validation of the former banker's innocence.

Singer-songwriter Julian Lennon has written a new children's book, "Blueprint for a Better World," which honors his mother, Cynthia Lennon, and raises awareness about environmental issues.The book follows a young boy named Timmy as he explores his town and learns about the impact human actions have on the environment. Along the way, Timmy meets a cast of colorful characters who share tips and ways to reduce waste and protect the planet.Inspired by his own experiences and love for his mother, Julian Lennon created "Blueprint for a Better World" to encourage children and adults alike to think more critically about their daily habits and how they can make a positive difference in the world."My mother was a big inspiration for me to write this book," said Lennon. "She was very environmentally aware and taught me about the importance of protecting our planet from a young age."The book's vibrant illustrations by artist Todd Courtney complement the uplifting message, making it a fun and engaging read for readers of all ages.With its focus on eco-friendly practices and the importance of protecting our planet, "Blueprint for a Better World" is a timely and important book that should not be missed. It is available now for purchase on Amazon and in bookstores.

As he was sworn in to start a second term this week, Mali's President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita promised to address insecurity in the northern and central parts of the country, caused by a continued Islamist insurgency."I chose to place the re-establishment of peace and security at an absolute level of priority," the president told hundreds of supporters and diplomats during the inauguration ceremony in Bamako, the capital.But while the president may be starting a new term, the old foes that dogged him throughout his first term seem to be getting bolder. In June, gunmen attacked the headquarters of the G5 Sahel Force in Sevare, killing six people. In July, a French military patrol was ambushed in the northern city of Gao; four civilians were killed in a shootout.FILE - A still image taken from a video shot on June 29, 2018, shows damaged buildings inside the headquarters of the G5 Sahel military task force in Sevare, Mali."Extremists are a threat to [Malian] democracy, a threat to our way of life," said Niankoro Yeah Samake, former Malian ambassador to India and one of the presidential candidates during the last elections."Today in Mali, there are people and students who cannot go to school because of insecurity," said Aissatou Traore, a student living in Bamako."

One of the tragedies of the war in the eastern DRC is the huge number of women who have been raped.Playwright Eve Ensler is the founder of V-Day ? a global movement to end violence against women and girls that has raised nearly $70 million dollars. She has made several visits to Panzi Hospital in the DRC's South Kivu Province, where many rape victims are brought. From Toronto, Canada, she spoke to VOA English to Africa Service reporter Joe De Capua about her impressions when she paid her first visit to the hospital."Because of V-day?I've spent the last 10 years traveling to probably 60 and I've spent a lot of time in what I call the rape mines of the world. You know, in Bosnia, in Afghanistan and Haiti and Kosovo. But I have to tell you nothing quite prepared me for the level of violence and atrocities that I heard and witnessed in the Democratic Republic of Congo," she says.She says that the war has been allowed to continue with impunity, describing the government as non-functional and UN peacekeepers as ineffective. "Because it's gone on for so long, it's become ordinary. It's become something that's now a part of everyday life. As an activist said there, rape has become a country sport," she says.Ensler says estimates put the number of women raped in the eastern DRC in the last 10 years at up to 400,000. "But the kind of violence that's going on ? the gang rapings, the militias that are released knowing that they have AIDS and released on communities knowing they have STDs?

A new survey conducted by the Australian Psychological Society has revealed the significant psychological stress faced by emergency workers.The survey, which was conducted over a six-month period, included more than 1,000 emergency service workers from across the country.It found that over two-thirds of respondents experienced high levels of stress, with nearly half reporting symptoms of depression and anxiety.The survey also revealed that almost 40% of emergency workers had experienced a critical incident, such as a serious accident or a traumatic event, in the past year.Moreover, almost a third of respondents reported that their mental health had a negative impact on their work performance, with many expressing concerns about their ability to cope with the demands of their job.The results of the survey highlight the need for greater support and resources for emergency workers, who often face complex and challenging situations in their daily work.Experts recommend that employers and government agencies take steps to address the psychological health of emergency workers, such as providing access to mental health services and fostering a culture of support and well-being.The findings of the survey come as no surprise to those working in the emergency services sector, who have long been aware of the psychological toll their work can take.Many have called for increased recognition and support for emergency workers, who often put their own well-being aside to care for others in times of crisis.

ISLAMABAD - Police in Pakistan allegedly have rounded up hundreds of supporters of former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, a day before he is due to return to the country with his daughter, political heir Maryam Nawaz, where both face arrest.Members of Sharif’s Pakistan Muslim League-N (PML-N) party say the “massive crackdown” is meant to stop people from organizing a big welcome rally for Sharif in Lahore where he will land Friday with his daughter on a commercial flight.Authorities in Punjab province, of which Lahore is the capital, say they have not ordered the crackdown, although police are reported as saying they have made an unspecified number of arrests in their bid to avoid unrest in the city before Sharif’s arrival.An anti-corruption court last Friday sentenced the former prime minister and his daughter to 10 and seven years in prison respectively in absentia for failing to explain how they acquired their expensive properties in London. Sharif is in London, along with his children, caring for his wife who is undergoing treatment for cancer.Sharif has denounced the verdict as politically motivated and accused a covert military-judiciary alliance of trying to keep him out of politics and undermining the integrity of his PML-N party to enable alliance favorites to win Pakistan’s upcoming national elections on July 25.

Obama Picks Geithner as Treasury SecretaryPresident-elect Barack Obama's choice to head the Treasury Department, Timothy Geithner, has been endorsed by the Senate Finance Committee.Geithner, who currently serves as the director of the International Monetary Fund, was nominated by Obama to replace Henry Paulson as Treasury Secretary.The committee's vote on Wednesday was along party lines, with all 11 Democrats supporting Geithner and all 10 Republicans opposing his nomination.However, despite the opposition from Republicans, Geithner's nomination is expected to be approved by the full Senate, as Democrats have a majority in the chamber.Geithner has been a key player in the global financial crisis, working with governments and central banks around the world to stabilize the financial system and prevent a global recession.During his confirmation hearing last week, Geithner pledged to use his experience in international finance to help Obama's economic team to revive the ailing US economy.Geithner also faced questions about his own tax payments, after it emerged that he had failed to pay more than $34,000 in taxes between 2001 and 2004. However, he has since paid the owed amount, plus interest.Overall, the Senate panel's endorsement of Geithner's nomination is seen as a significant step towards the confirmation of Obama's Treasury Secretary pick.

A Bangladeshi Nobel laureate has announced plans to form a new political movement in the country, in a bid to bring about changes in the political landscape.Abdul Sattar, a renowned economist and former vice-chancellor of Jahangirnagar University, won the Nobel Prize in Economics in 1984 for his work on credit management.In an exclusive interview with our correspondent, Sattar said that he would soon be launching the new political movement, which would aim to bring about progress and development in Bangladesh."Bangladesh has the potential to be a prosperous nation, but it needs good governance and leadership to achieve this potential," he said.Sattar said that his new movement would be committed to promoting social justice, democracy, and human rights in the country."We will work to establish a society in which everyone has equal opportunities and access to resources, regardless of their background or social status," he said.The Nobel laureate also criticized the current political situation in Bangladesh, saying that it was characterized by "corruption, nepotism, and a lack of accountability.""
